column2: WASHINGTON, June 6.--The largest student body ever graduated from the Catholic University of America will receive degrees from that institution at the commencement exercises on Wednesday.

Although reluctant to surrender her Wimbledon crown by default, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, so long the queen of the women's tennis realm, is accepting philosophically the fact that she is unable to make the trip to England this year.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., June 6.-- Bernard F. Gimbel of Port Chester, N.Y., won the first and third places in the $500 Champion Hunter Stake, the final of three title events which today brought to a close the annual Tuxedo horse show.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., June 6.-- The Westchester amateur golf championship is still an enigma to Richard A. Jones Jr. of Westchester Hills. For the past ten years Dick has aimed for the title and three times during the last six tournaments he has been a finalist.

THE early bird won the British open championship. Tommy Armour was among the first to finish at Carnoustie, and that helped his chances. He didn't know what he had to do to win, so he just went along and played golf. With his 296 on the scoreboard, following players had a mark to shoot at and, strictly according to custom, they went over it like high hurdlers.
ONE hundred years ago tomorrow died Sarah Siddons, in whose person the British matron was sublimated into the Muse of Tragedy.

IN an ironic series of essays on the big town of modern America Mr. Philip McKee has ex pressed himself in a book which has lost much of the point through our familiarity with the thesis.
Kou Walters from Tallinn, Estonia, the capital formerly known as Reval, finished in New York a few weeks ago an 11,000-mile voyage in a twenty-eight-foot sloop.
MADRID, June 6 (AP).--The members of the First Spanish Republican Cabinet since 1873 turned tonight from administrative cares to electioneering.

FOR the confirmed book-lover, and especially for the collector this is one of the most delightful of books. It was written in the middle years of the last century, but its quality is timeless.
BALTIMORE, June 6 (AP).--Urging war on racketeering, Deets Pickett, research secretary of the Methodist Episcopal Board of Temperance, said today democracy was at stake in America.

NANKING, May 11.--Detailed plans for curbing the powers of military leaders so effectively as to minimize the chances for starting future civil wars have been worked out by the delegates to the National People's Convention.

SAO PAULO, June 4.--The coffee conference was again delayed this week through the inability of the Brazilian delegates to agree upon united plans.

ON a long skeleton steel structure an airplane is gripped in the vise-like jaws of a traveling car. It strains at its an chorage as the pilot tests the full power of the motor with a mighty roar. Satisfied, he nods to the attending group.

Sale of the old Ward Estate property at Spuyten Duyvil which will be held by Joseph P. Day on the premises on Saturday, June 20, will open up sixty-three lots, restricted to plots of 50 by 100 feet or larger, for residential development. In addition the old Ward home and two other dwellings will be sold.
Security of title to land formerly under water within Greater New York, elsewhere than in the Borough of Manhattan, worth many millions of dollars, is affected by the recent amendment of Section 14.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 4.--There will assemble at VT Park next Monday a group of savants and sportsmen, lovers of outdoors and persons interested in the use of Uncle Sam's domain for grazing of livestock.

The "Warehouse Gang," a band of thugs whose specialty is holding up department store distributing stations in Queens, attempted unsuccessfully early yesterday morning to obtain a $5,000 payroll from the safe of the Flushing warehouse of R.H. Macy Co.
WHAT with one thing and another, woman's place in these days seems to be as extensive as that needle point on which the scholastics of the Middle Ages poised an indefinite number of angels.

SCHOHARIE, N.Y., June 6 (AP).-- After hearing arguments on a motion to vacate the stay of trial granted Jack (Legs) Diamond, Supreme Court Justice E. Walter Bliss reserved decision today. He indicated he would return his decision Wednesday. The trial is set for June 15.
LONDON, June 6.--Tommy Armour, British open golf champion, left London today for Southampton and the United States, hoping to win the United States open for a double.

PARIS, June 5.--The month preceding the Grand Prix always is a time for many leading charities to give gala performances. This year is no exception. Within the last few days several notable entertainments have been held for the relief of the suffering and for general welfare.

EXETER, N.H., June 6.--Exeter won the fifty-first annual baseball game from Andover by a score of 4 to 2 today before a record-breaking attendance of 4,500, including 3,000 alumni gathered here for the sesquicentennial exercises.

Mayor Walker complained yesterday that there were two difficulties he always faced as head of the administration. The first was that each year added five years to his age, and the second was that his serious utterances were greeted with the remark: "Isn't he funny?"

With more than a million students crowding our colleges, haw can a university prevent an individual from being lost in the crowd? How can a university secure those values which arise when education is an individual process?
WORCESTER, Mass., June 6.-- Holy Cross added the third member of the Big Three to its 1931 baseball victims today when it defeated Harvard, 10 to 3.

The Legal Centre at the University of Michigan, providing facilities for research and practice in law under unified control, on the same plan that the Medical Centre here provides for the physician and surgeon, will be completed within six months, it was declared yesterday.

PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, June 6. --Rain stymied most of the competitors in the first qualifying round of the women's British open golf championship today, driving a number to shelter and playing havoc with scores. It could not mar, however, the brilliance of Miss Enid Wilson, former titleholder.
THE Kroll Oper in Berlin may become a "radio theatre," according to the Berlin Vossische Zeitung of May 22, which quotes Sieben Tage to this effect.

LAWRENCE, Kan., June 6.-- Trouble within the faculty at the University of Kansas became public today when Chancellor E.H. Lindley's bulletin listed twenty members of it as having resigned. Two widely known professors, R.J. Heilman and A.A. Schaeffer, immediately said they had not retired voluntarily.
IN our great charter of independence Thomas Jefferson wrote that "gov ernments are instituted among men, deriving their just powers from the consent of the governed."

For the first time since he entered the professional ranks, William Tilden will wield his racquet in the service of charity today when a series of exhibition tennis matches will be held at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, for the benefit of the Actors' Fund of America.

Thirteen places will be at stake tomorrow when 154 golfers, amateurs and professionals, start on their first step toward the national open-- the sectional qualifying round for the metropolitan district.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 6.--Edward Jacobs of Baltimore, after eliminating J. Gilbert Hall of Orange in the semi-final round, won in straight sets from Samuel Gilpin of Philadelphia in the final of the New England tennis championship today.

TABULATION of the 1930 census is disclosing that there are not so many radio sets in the country as many of the esti mates indicate. The census enumerators asked, "Do you own a radio set?"

BARCELONA, June 5.--Catalonia has acquired habits of secretiveness as a result of long necessity for carrying on under cover away from the official eye of Madrid. Although it has now shaken off the hostile Central Government the habit is still strong.

OTTAWA, June 4.--With much grumbling over the painful necessities of the situation, but with a philosophical determination to see the business through, the great Canadian taxpayer is reaching into his pocket to meet the cost to Canada of the world-wide depression.
IN 1921 Sacheverell Sitwell published the first three cantos of his poem "Doctor Donne and Gargantua." The present volume includes those cantos, together with three more.
LONDON, Sunday, June 7 (AP).-- England was shaken from one end to the other at 1:30 this morning by an earthquake shock which sent thousands of people rushing into the streets in alarm.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 6. --Mrs. Geraldine Livingston Thompson of Red Bank, leader in New Jersey social work, received in the honorary degree of Master of Philanthropy at the tenth annual commencement of the New Jersey College for Women, which was held today.
The new Arnold Pavilion for children at St. Luke's Convalescent Hospital on King Street, Greenwich, Conn., will be ready for occupancy in October, it is reported.

GAS, oil, air and water may be all that today's motorist needs to add to an automobile for a trip, but if he is interested in the comforts that bring more smiles to the gallon he will include additional accessories.

SAO PAULO, May 17.--A group of business men are organizing a company to salvage the old Spanish Royal Mail liner, the Principe Asturias, which ran on the rocks off the coast of San Sebastian a few miles north of Santos, in 1915.

OPENING a series of three Sunday broadcasts dealing with the Russian five-year plan, the Duchess of Atholl, speak ing from London, will be heard here at 12:30 P.M., over WABC's network. The Duchess will discuss the operation of the plan from the point of view of capitalist industry.

Degrees will be confered on the largest graduating class in the history of the College of the City of New York at the eighty-fifth annual commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium on June 17, Dr. Morton Gottschall, registrar, announced yesterday. More than 12,000 are expected to witness the ceremonies.

Strength in foreign loans was again a feature of dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Led by Argentine Government bonds, the South American list advanced and gains of a point or more were not infrequent.

Dispatches from Europe predicting that Germany would seek a moratorium on the postponable portion of the reparations payments provoked discussion among bankers last week as to the probable effects of such action in the financial markets of the world.

Mrs. Anne Stillman McCormick received no settlement from her divorced husband, James A. Stillman, but her four children were "amply provided for," it was revealed yesterday by lawyers connected with the case.

CHICAGO, June 6.--Federal prosecutors today centred their attention on plans for an early trial of Al Capone on his indictments charging the evasion of $215,000 in income taxes.

The sales of the leading chain store and mail order companies in this country continued to fall slightly behind last year during the month of May, according to estimates based on a compilation of the first thirtyfour companies to report for last month, or for their latest four-week reporting period.

WASHINGTON, June 6.--Assignments of the midshipmen who were graduated from the Naval Academy yesterday and commissioned as ensigns are announced by the Navy Department. The ensigns, after a period of leave, will go to their ships and stations.

An admonition that in carrying the gospel into foreign lands the minister of Christ must adapt His teachings to native customs and traditions was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Alvin E. Magary in his sermon to the outgoing missionaries of the Presbyterian Church.

A hitherto unrecorded miniature of Robert Burns, believed to be the one for which the Scottish poet sat in 1795 at about the time he wrote the line "A man's a man for a' that," is reproduced in the issue of The Colophon, book collectors' quarterly, published today.

WASHINGTON, June 7.--Although the Chequers conference is characterized by the Hoover Administration as of no material concern to the United States, it is apparent nevertheless that its attitude toward today's momentous gathering of British and German statesmen is more than that of a passive observer.

BUENOS AIRES, June 7.--Peso exchange continued during the past week to be the subject of sharp fluctuations, which indicated it had not settled down toward any fixed tendency, despite the Bank of the Nation's efforts to bring about its stabilization through an agreement with private bankers that they prevent speculation.

CHICAGO, June 7.--The live stock industry is in a rather chaotic condition. Supplies of cattle are only about 4,000 above the smallest week of the year, while supplies of hogs are 8,000 larger than the year's smallest run, and supplies of sheep are 10,000 above the smallest of the year.

Despite the economic depression substantial gains in facilities for public recreation were made in 1930, according to the Year Book of the National Recreation Association, which has just been issued.

Horne of the School of Education of New York University in an address tonight at the annual convention of the National Association of Jewish Centre Executives at Camp Scopus here.

TORONTO, Ont., June 7.--Speakers at the World Convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union declared today that governmental liquor control had failed in Canada and Sweden and acclaimed the United States as "blazing the right trail to prohibition."

Kain, rector of All Staints' Church, San Diego, Cal., preached yesterday morning in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

NORFOLK, Va., June 7.--Fire, caused by an explosion aboard an oil barge, destroyed an area of six square blocks along the waterfront and in the wholesale business section of Norfolk late today, doing damage estimated at from $3,000,000 to $5,000,000.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., June 7.-- Fifty-three trees were dedicated today at the National Farm School in celebration of Founders Day at that institution for under-privileged boys of the cities of America. They had been planted in memory of living and deal benefactors of the school.

Columbia University is to receive a $2,000,000 endowment gift to establish a Graduate School of International Affairs, according to an announcement yesterday by Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary.

Hopping's hard riding team of Reds went on to defeat Tommy Hitchcock Jr's. quartet of Whites after five minutes of a sudden-death overtime session, 11 to 10, in the second encounter of the Sunday highgoal polo series today at the Sands Point Club.

A.B. Kinsolving, deliver his last sermon to them as the opening of commencement week.

Philip Perkins, former British amateur champion and rapidly becoming one of the outstanding golfers in America.

Being men of singularly diversifed attainments with whom variety is regarded as one of life's choicest morsels, the Yankees chose to turn in a performance that bordered very close to perfection at the Stadium yesterday as they vanquished the Indians, to square the current fourgame series at one victory apiece.

HAVANA, June 7.--A big man with a strong jaw, twinkling eyes, a man of iron-gray hair, a vibrant personality and an enormous gusto for living is out fishing today on the gunboat that serves as his Presidential yacht, while here in his torrid capital men sit at cafe tables discussing "la revolucion" which has been threatening for a year and which somehow never arrives.
WASHINGTON, June 7.--The gift of $100,000 from an anonymous donor for construction work at Washington Cathedral was announced today by the Right Rev. James E. Freeman, Bishop of Washington.

POUGHKEEPSIE, June 9.--Urging more attention by college students to governmental problems, Governor Roosevelt delivered the commencement address at Vassar College today. WASHINGTON, June 14.--Refunding operations in connection with the government's public debt of some $16,500,000,000 between Jan. 1 and June 1 have resulted in a saving of about $14,000,000 in interest. The service for the "setting apart" of women as deaconesses in the Protestant Episcopal Church should occupy the same position in the ordinal as the office for the ordination of a deacon, says the report of the joint commission on adapting the office of deaconess to the tasks of the church, which will be presented to the triennial convention of that communion in Denver in September.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 19 (AP). --General Juan Vicente Gomez, former President and dominating figure in Venezuelan politics for more than twenty years, was unanimously elected President of Venezuela today to fill the unexpired term of Dr. Juan Bautista Perez, who resigned last week at the demand of Congress. The term runs until April, 1936.

With District Attorney Edwards still refusing to believe that Starr Faithfull committed suicide, Inspector Harold R. King, chief of Nassau County detectives, revealed yesterday that he had received information which, if true, would solve the mystery of her death at Long Beach.

The Rev. Robert A. Skinner of the Paulist Church, Winchester, Tenn., has been appointed by the Very Rev. John B. Harney, the superior general of the Paulist Community, as pastor of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

LONDON, Saturday, June 20.--Information that President Hoover had announced he was conferring with party leaders on measures to assist in economic recovery abroad and to strengthen the situation in Germany reached London newspapers close to midnight.

PITTSBURGH, June 19.--Samuel McClay, who numbered among his law partners two United States Senators, Philander C. Knox and David A. Reed, and a former judge, James H. Reed, died today at his home here.

HARRISBURG, Pa., June 19.--Uniform labor legislation was recommended today for adoption by the representatives of ten States who participated in the Eastern Interstate conference called by Governor Pinchot to consider that subject. The reports of committees were adopted after full discussion at a general meeting.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 19.-- Two brand new finalists have made their way into the last round of the metropolitan amateur championship which will be played at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club tomorrow over thirty-six holes.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19.-- There were forty-two yachts gathered tonight for the ocean yacht race to Cape May which starts tomorrow. Several may be added to the fleet, so that it promises to be the largest one that ever set sail in an offshore contest. Forty-one in the Bermuda race a year ago was the record.

GENEVA, June 19.--This was a decisive day in the Conference for the Limitation of the Manufacture of Narcotics, and its decision was welcomed by veteran anti-narcotic leaders, such as A.E. Blanco, as "bringing the limitation convention out of the woods at last."

WASHINGTON, June 19.--Marie Averil Bland, a Canadian war nurse, to whom naturalization was refused by the United States Supreme Court, petitioned the court today for a rehearing, following the course already taken by Dr. Douglas C. Macintosh, a Canadian war chaplain who was also rejected.

Albert Goldman, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, testified yesterday at the Attorney General's inquiry into stock-selling activities of the New York City Airport, Inc. He said that his name had been used without his knowledge or consent in the corporation's literature and newspaper advertisements.

PASADENA, Cal., June 19.--New evidence that a prehistoric man of high cultural development existed in the southwestern part of what is now the United States from 10,000 to 20,-- 000 years ago and hunted red-haired sloths and giant buffalo, now extinct, was presented to the American Association for the Advancement of Science here today.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 19.--While there have been some bathers at Bailey's Beach during the past week, the beach will not be officially opened for the season until today. The opening this year has been delayed until the new pavilion and the other improvements were entirely completed.

WASHINGTON, June 19.--Retail food prices followed the lead of wholesale commodities in May, tumbling 2 per cent, as compared with the previous month and showing an average decrease of 19 1-3 per cent since May 15 one year ago, according to a survey by the Bureau of Labor Statistics based on reports from fifty-one cities.

Carr, vice president of the International Association of Machinists. About 8,000 employee are affected.

ST. LOUIS, June 19.--The Yankees chimed in so boisterously today with Lou Gehrig's plane for a birthday celebration that the St. Louis Browns got lost somewhere and became pallid patches in the dusty background. Lou's buddies collaborated with him in a shocker of nineteen hits for a 16-to-5 victory as the first item of their season's second Western excursion.

PARIS, June 19.--The Soviet foreign trade policy is now undergoing an evolution which perhaps has escaped the notice of Americans in the uproar about "Soviet dumping" and the "Red trade menace," but, nevertheless, is of considerable importance.

ROME, June 19.--With intent to rectify certain false impressions and rumors spread abroad concerning the Italo-Vatican controversy, official Italian circles today broke the silence assiduously maintained since the delivery of the Vatican note on Monday.

Sizzling under a sun which sent the official mercury to 86 degrees, New York suffered yesterday the opening of a heat wave which the Weather Bureau said last night was likely to continue today. Rogers Hornsby's Cubs unsheathed their claws at Ebbets Field yesterday, and by the time the long nineinning contest was over the Robins were pretty much in shreds and Bob Smith was able to boast the achievement of his seventh seasonal triumph.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 19.-- Harvard's varsity crew is still looking for the eight that can stop it. Racing upstream against the night, Harvard just beat darkness into the shadows of Bartlett's Cove, victor over Yale for the first time since 1927 and completing the first undefeated Harvard rowing season in a good many years.

MADRID, June 19.--A preliminary draft of the Constitution of the new Spanish Republic has been completed by a subcommittee and will be submitted to the drafting committee for approval or modification and later will be submitted by the government to the Cortes when it meets July 14.

HUNTINGTON BAY, L.I., June 19.--Amid the plaudits of one of the largest gatherings that has crowded the rails of the show ring of the Huntington Bay Club, President Frederick D. Perching for his book, "My Experiences in the World War," just published here.

WASHINGTON, June 19.--With prompt action promised by the Interstate Commerce Commission on the railroads' request for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates, letters of protest and approval continued to pour in to the commission today.

ST. JOHN, N.B., June 19.--Otto Hillig and Holger Hoiriis, flying from Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., to Newfoundland on their way to Denmark, brought their plane down here tonight at 8:30 o'clock, Eastern Daylight Time.

WASHINGTON, June 19.--Admiral Wiliam V. Pratt, Chief of Naval Operations, admitted today that a "padlock" order was issued last week forbidding heads of naval bureaus and other officers in executive position in the Navy Department to disclose matters discussed in conferences held in the office of the Secretary of the Navy, unless "word to the contrary" is uttered by the "supervising authority."

PARIS, June 19.--It was announced here this afternoon that the Bank of France had granted a credit to Spain of 300,000,000 francs (about $12,000,000). The money has been given on a short-term basis and is guaranteed by gold deposits in London.

David Jones of Columbia and Harry Hendlin of North Carolina, the two top-seeded players in the Eastern intercollegiate lawn tennis championship, reached the final yesterday and will meet for the title at 2 P.M. today on the turf courts of the Crescent A.C. in Bay Ridge.

LONDON, June 19.--Woolworth shares again continued to attract chief attention on the Stock Exchange today. The ordinary shares at one time recovered to 4 d premium from a discount of 3d overnight. The scrip closed at par. Dealings in the preference ranged between 4 d and 9d premium.
William L. Ward, veteran Republican leader of Westchester County, returned yesterday on the Cunarder Berengaria from a tour through France and England.

WASHINGTON, June 19.--Service organizations should begin now to prepare for the heavy demands that will be made on them next Winter to care for the unemployed, William Green, President of the American Federation of Labor, said in a radio speech tonight over the National Broadcasting System.

MEXICO CITY, June 19.--The law approved yesterday by the Vera Cruz State Legislature limiting the number of priests there to one for every 100,000 inhabitants finds a strong reaction today in a declaration issued from the Apostolic headquarters over the signature of Archbishop Leopoldo Ruiz y Flores.

The Rev. Samuel Ludlow, who had been pastor of the Church of the Holy Innocents in West Thirty-seventh Street, west of Broadway, since 1923, died Thursday night of a sudden attack of heart disease in the rectory of his church. He had been ill, but his condition had not been regarded as critical.

While retailers continued to place a large volume of reorders for popularpriced sales merchandise in the local wholesale markets during the week, the total was somewhat below the previous week. Stores are now turning their attention to Fall lines.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 21.-- Death halted a merry picnic party at Brattle Street and Fresh Pond Parkway here today when a truck carrying a group of boys and girls crashed with a motor car, killing one youth, injuring another and a woman so severely that they may die, and inflicting minor injuries on twenty others. All of the boys and girls on the truck and the five older persons in the automobile were injured.

NEW HAVEN, June 21.--About 3,000 librarians and library trustees are gathering this week at Yale University for the annual conference of the American Library Association. Adam Strohm, librarian of the Detroit Public Library and president of the association, will preside at the general sessions.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 21.-- Delightful weather attracted throngs to the Beach Club today. Many luncheons were given at the clubhouse.

BARCELONA, Spain, June 21.-- The eyes of Spain were focused on Barcelona today, when Alejandro Lerroux, Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Madrid Government and a leading light in the Conservative Republican firmament, addressed a billowing crowd of 40,000 in a bull-fight arena here and opened a frank drive to break the power of President Macia of the Catalan Generalidad.

Striking a submerged log in the middle of the Hudson off 189th Street shortly before 9 o'clock last night, the 30-foot sedan runabout Marvin filled and sank almost immediately. Samuel Untermyer, since 1926 a leading figure in the movement for rapid transit unification as well as the Federal and State court battles to preserve the five-cent fare, announced yesterday his resignation as special counsel for the Transit Commission. LONDON, June 22.--With flags flying all over the British Empire in his honor and guns booming the royal salute, the Prince of Wales will spend his thirty-seventh birthday tomorrow in working as usual.

ST. JOHN, N.B., June 22.--Fire swept the western half of St. John's harbor today, destroying shipping, government property, elevators and houses. Estimates of the loss run from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000.

A group consisting of most of the best-known writers and authorities on contract bridge has agreed to sanction a new system of bidding, now being worked out, in order to "end the confusion of countless bidding systems," it was announced yesterday.

Chief Mike Payan, Yaqui Indian from Arizona, made an impressive debut last night in Madison Square Garden when he won the decision from Jackie Purvis, Indianapolis welterweight, in the feature six-round bout of a new talent show which attracted only 1,500 spectators.

WESTBUR.Y, L. I., June 22.-Pouring six goals between the posts in the last two chukkers, Templeton turned back the Aiken Knights, 12 to 6, in a semi-final match for the Third Westbury Challenge Cup at the Meadow Brook Club today.

WIMBLEDON STADIUM, England, June 22 (N.A.N.A.).--Ideal weather favored the opening day of the Wimbledon championship play today. Everything was in perfect order for the start, and there was a big crowd present to see what promised to be an excellent afternoon's sport.

ROME, June 22.--The Italian Government's complete approval of what was termed "President Hoover's magnificent gesture," was expressed by official circles today, although it was made quite clear that this would result in financial loss to Italy.

VIENNA, June 22.--Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, who lectured Saturday at the University of Vienna and in the Austrian Parliament tonight on "The Republican Form of Government," had a long talk today with Mayor Seitz and spent the morning looking over what Vienna socialism has done for the city's citizens.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, June 22. --The crippled submarine Nautilus, bearing Sir Hubert Wilkins and his party toward a journey under the ice of the Atlantic, limped into Cobh harbor this afternoon, sadly battered and bruised by her tedious seventeenday journey across much of the Atlantic in tow.

PARIS, June 22.--Under the influence of government inspiration and the biggest bull market the Bourse has had in many months, French opinion on the Hoover plan was modified considerably today. When the trial of Robert Walsh, 22 years old, and three other men on a first degree murder indictment in the shooting of a York Avenue garage cashier during a hold-up last January was resumed in General Sessions yesterday, Judge Koenig denied the motion of defense counsel for a mistrial.

PARIS, June 22.--French tennis officials were almost ready to hang crepe on the Davis Cup today when the news of Henri Cochet's defeat at the hands of an unseeded player at Wimbledon reached this city.

LONDON, June 22.--President Hoover's plan to suspend war debt payments for a year has had a tonic effect on the British stock market.
WASHINGTON, June 22.--Praise for President Hoover's proposed oneyear suspension of intergovernmental debts and war reparations continued unabated at the Capitol today, but with some qualifications.
CHICAGO, June 22.--All markets in Chicago swept sharply higher today as bullish enthusiasm gained ground following President Hoover's announcement of a proposed year's moratorium of war debts.

HAVANA, June 22.--Disturbances continued in various localities of Cuba today, especially in Matanzas, where the opening of the trial of students and laborers accused of placing bombs and plotting a rebellion provoked much excitement.

N.J., June 22.-- Dan Williams, Shackamaxon Country Club professional, and his star pupil, Miss Charlotte Glutting, winner of the recent championship of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association, won low gross honors in a mined foursome medal-play competition today at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club by the New Jersey Professional Golfers' Association. Trading on the Cotton Exchange reached yesterday the largest volume in a year and prices rose violently. PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 5.--Merger negotiations between the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and Bethlehem Steel will be resumed in the Fall, according to reports in steel circles here. CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- The tenth renewal of the $5,000 Rainy Day Sweepstakes, feature of the Grand Circuit program at North Randall, resulted in a split-heat race, which was won by Brevere, chestnut colt, owned by W.N. Reynolds of Winston-Salem N.C., and driven by Ben White of Lexington, Ky.

ST. LOUIS. July 6 (AP).--Ellsworth Vines and Keith Gledhill, two tall and youthful Californians, won the national clay court doubles tennis championship at the Triple A Club today, defeating Berkeley Bell, New York, formerly of Texas, and Bruce Barnes, Austin, Texas, in the final.

I am glad to announce that the American proposal for one year's postponement of all intergovernmental debts and reparations has now been accepted in principle by all of the important creditor governments.

Buyers from the Coast and Southwest led in the placing of Fall orders in the market here yesterday, resident buyers reported. A heavier rep-resentation of buyers from Middle Nest and Southern stores is expected here next week. The volume of purchasing was described as encouraging.

William Tilden, seven times winner of the national amateur tennis championship, will make his first appearance in a national professional tournament at 2 P.M. today, when he engages James Burns Sr. of the Rockaway Hunting Club on the stadium court of the West Side Tennis Club.
LONDON, July 6.--Immense relief spread over London tonight when the news came that the Paris debt negotiations had been successful.

TOLEDO, July 6.--At the end of the longest trail ever followed in thirty-five years of championship history, Billy Burke, 28-year-old professional at the Round Hill Club in Greenwich, Conn., former steel mill worker, has stepped into Bobby Jones's shoes as the national open golf champion.

ALBANY, July 6.--Governor Roosevelt in a statement issued here today expressed the hope that the ruling of the board of review of the United States Labor Department which declared that his conditional pardon of one Philip Paone was "valueless," will be tested in the courts. The board recommended that the deportation proceed.

WASHINGTON, July 6.--Announcement that his proposal for a year's holiday in the payment of intergovernmental debts and reparations had been accepted in principle by all the nations involved was made by President Hoover at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 (AP).--Chicago could do nothing with Heinie Meine until two were out in the ninth inning today, and Pittsburgh defeated the Cubs, 5 to 2. Meine held the visitors to six hits and had his second successive shutout in sight when Hemsley's triple scored Stephenson and the Cub catcher tallied as Grimm singled.

Governor Roosevelt returned yesterday from Virginia, where he was hailed by leaders of his party as the next Democratic nominee for President, as reticent as ever when questioned regarding the progress of his Presidential boom and as insistent as before that he was not interested in national politics but devoting his undivided attention to the responsibilities of his present office.

George L. Baker, Mayor of Portland, Ore., who went abroad with the group of American Mayors who were guests of the French Government, returned yesterday on the French liner He de France and added his version to the many descriptions of the tour given last month when the main body of touring Mayors returned.

MOSCOW, July 8.--Close on the heels of the publication of Joseph Stalin's speech demanding greater efficiency in Soviet industry, a powerful edict was printed on the first pages of the newspapers today calling for a rejuvenation of the coal industry in the Donetz Basin.

Following Tuesday's sharp upward trend, the real estate market yesterday settled down to a quieter pace. The usual run of changes in fee and leasehold control was reported, but mortgage placements were made in larger volume and covered a wide area in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Westchester. Some 5 per cent money was in evidence.

LONDON, July 8.--Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, arrived here recently for a month's visit, determined to make only one speech in London, which he delivered today at a luncheon of the Individualist Club. His theme was a newer, freer measure of human liberty, in the spirit of which, he said, the people were now being integrated, rather than under the old system of nation building.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that old Russian debts, contracted previous to the stabilization of the ruble by the Soviet Government, could not be collected at gold value. The implication was that such debts could not be collected at all, since the old ruble was worthless.

The elimination of trolley lines, subway kiosks and exterior electric signs and the substitution of asphalt pavement for Belgian blocks was recommended at a meeting of the Fourth Avenue Improvement Committee and the Central Mercantile Association held yesterday at the Manhattan Club.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8.--The Giants lost a game in the ninth today which they seemingly had won as early as the third, thereby adding still further testimony to the belief that if John McGraw is ever to bag a pennant this year the grand old master will have to get down to the playing weight of his good old Oriole days and take an active hand in the matter himself.

Dr. Maurice T. Lewis, president of the Bay Ridge Savings Bank, who had been practicing medicine in Brooklyn for more than forty years, died last night at his home, 404 Fifty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, at the age of 64, after a lingering illness. He is survived by a widow, Alida Fraim Lewis, and a daughter, Mrs. Ruth Lewis Hailer of Frederick. Md.

LONDON, July 8.--Senator Guglielmo Marconi is now in London, but in the role of a business man rather than as the great wireless inventor, having come to attend meetings of companies of which he is a director.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--Reports were prevalent today that the administration was concerned as to whether President Hoover's debt suspension plan is actually in effect or will be made effective before July 15, when Germany, under the terms of the Young Plan, would be compelled to pay another instalment of reparations.

BROCKTON, Mass., July 8.--Five persons, including a mother and her son, are dead from drinking a mixture of denatured alcohol procured under the pretext that it was to be used to cut shellac, and two others, including the man who procured the liquor, are in the Brockton Hospital but expected to recover.

Reilly said: "I am well pleased, because every speakeasy and restaurant owner was aware of our coming, but it will be different when we make our secret visits some time before the end of the week."

LONDON, July 8.--Sir Oswald Mosley and three of his fellow-members of the "New party" today strode across the floor of the House of Commons and took seats on the Opposition benches in the midst of the Conservatives.

The new spick and span olive green subway cars for the city's Eighth Avenue line had their first test in actual operation yesterday when an eight-car train of the new cars entered service on the B. M. T. Sea Beach Line between Times Square and Stillwell Avenue, Coney Island.

Samuel Gordon sold the threestory brick apartment house with stores on a plot 40 by 107 feet at 167 and 169 Jackson Avenue, northwest corner of Stegman Street, Jersey City, subject to two mortgages totaling $69,000, to Sophie J. Rosenberg of New York.

BALTIMORE, July 8.-Mrs. William D. Bowie, member of a prominent old Virginia family and former treasurer of the Baltimore Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, died today at the Union Memorial Hospital here after a long illness.

CHICAGO, July 8 (AP).--Top Flight, the heavily backed favorite, won the $19,125 added Lassie Stakes by four lengths from a field of fourteen contenders at Arlington Park today. Modern Queen was second and Princess Camelia third.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--Chairman Smoot of the Senate Finance Com mittee, who has been engaged with Senator Robinson, the Democratic floor leader, in "a battle of statements" over the tariff, today demanded that the latter designate a specific schedule which he would revise downward.

Betty Smith, a young woman who insisted she had been framed by Chile Mapoca Acuna and four members of the vice squad, charged yesterday before members of the staff of Samuel Seabury, counsel for the Hofstadter committee, that a private detective had paid her $1,200 to stay away from New York to avoid giving testimony against the four policemen.

Official figures on the 1931 cotton acreage showing a reduction of only 10 per cent proved a disappointment and prices on the Cotton Exchange broke half a cent yesterday. Owing to the large carry-over expected on July 31, a decrease of 15 to 20 per cent had been hoped for.

An agreement between the Transit Commission and the B. M. T., holding up court action against the company for an accounting for about $6,500,000 alleged to have been improperly charged against joint operation under its contract with the city, was extended yesterday until Sept. 18.

A lively upturn in the last hour of trading on the Stock Exchange erased more than half of the early loss yesterday, but left final prices substantially below the final levels of the day before. Selling pressure was resumed at the opening of the market and continued, with occasional pauses, until about 2 o'clock.

At the beginning of the 1928 Presidential campaign Vice President Curtis rode in an ordinary Pullman car and did not mind it. His sister, Mrs. Edward Everett Gann, however, it was said, believed that her brother's dignity was being "outraged" by the campaign managers.

From the action of the stock market it might be inferred that the work of "profit-taking on good news" was pursued so promptly and rapidly on Tuesday that the realizing sales which were left to be effected yesterday were comparatively small.

Gifts and bequests to philanthropy in five of the principal cities of the United States during the first six months of this year reached a total of more than $188,055,074, of which $26,979,054 was for organized relief work, it was shown in the results of a survey made public here yesterday.

KALIMPONG, Bengal, India, July 8.--Several members of the expedition which will attempt to climb Mount Kanchenjunga, 28,146 feet high, have reached Kalimpong with me. The last two members of the party landed in India, from Germany ...

TORONTO, July 8 (AP).-The boys who play for the highest stakes in the realm of international golf today were champing at the bit and impatiently waiting for the rise of the barrier that will send off a select field of 154 aspirants tomorrow over beautiful Mississauga on the opening lap of the Canadian oven title chase.
At the national convention of the Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs in Richmond, Va., this week, President MARION McCLENCH made an address on economic leadership for women.

RYE, N.Y., July 8.--E. Ramey Donovan, Fordham freshman star, advanced along with three other players to the third round of the third annual invitation junior tennis singles tournament which started today at the Manursing Island Club.

The number of homicides per 100,000 of population in New York City in 1930 was virtually double the rate for the rest of the State and is the highest ever recorded, according to statistics made public yesterday by Commissioner Thomas Parran Jr. of the New York State Department of Health.

BUENOS AIRES, July 8.--Addreasing the United States Chamber of Commerce in Buenos Aires here today, Alejandro Bunge, who is a director of the Banco de la Nacion, predicted that Argentina's foreign trade for the year 1931 would show a favorable balance of 100,000,000 gold pesos, compared with an unfavorable balance of 120,000,000 gold pesos for 1930.

SOUTHAMPTON, N. Y., July 8.A large audience filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight when the Hampton play opened their fifth season under the direction of Henry Codman Potter and George Haight, with the presentation of "No Money to Guide Her," a new play by Leslie Squires.
DETROIT, July 8 (AP).--George Blaeholder tightened in the pinches today, and the Browns took the first game of their series with the Tigers by 7 to 1.

The annual race meet of the Suffolk Hounds, one of the old fixtures on Long Island, will be staged on Saturday at Southampton. The program of events is a strong one, with entries running high in each of the five events carded. The feature of the day's sport will be the East Hampton Cup Handicap.

WARSAW, July 8.--Sweeping changes are to be made in the administration of Eastern Galicia, the southeastern region of Poland, with a Ukrainian majority, with the expected appointment of former Minister of Finance Ignace Matuszewski...

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 8.-The two days' visit to the Berkshires of forty-two members of the Rye (N. Y.) Garden Club opened with showers, but the weather cleared before Miss Georgianna W. Sargent's tea party in their honor at the Pleasant Valley bird and wild flower sanctuary at Lenox.

NEWPORT, July 8.-The annual flower show of the Newport Garden Association and the Newport Horticultural Society at the Casino today was of particular interest to the members of the Summer colony. The exhibitions from the gardens at Seaverge of Mrs. Edward V. Hartford,...

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 8.Favorites fared poorly in the racing today at the Eastern States Exposition Oval. Three of the public choices out of four events on the card failed to reward their backers, but close finishes and fast time were a compensation.

Long Island College hospital receives $250,000 outright and a contingent bequest of $100,000 under the will of Dr. John Osborn Polak, president of the hospital's board of regents and prominent Brooklyn surgeon, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Brooklyn.

Payments which John C. Weston, former prosecutor in Women's Court, asserts were made to him by defense attorneys appearing in that court, were "like tips to a waiter," he declared yesterday as the disbarment trial of the fourteen lawyers named by him continued before Referee Clarence J. Shearn, and Weston spent his third day under interrogation.
During the recess of Congress it is difficult for any Republican to get into the newspapers except the President and those who have been working with him.

Further corporate integration of the New York Central Lines is shown in the annual report for 1930, issued yesterday. Substantial increases in the holdings of controlled lines, besides the acquisition or progress of acquisition of short lines in New York Central territory, are noted.

CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP).--Nedda Guy, owned by the Goodtime Stable of Goshen, N. Y., and driven by Walter Cox in the first heat and Harry Stokes in the second and third, won the annual renewal of the $12,000 Stallion Stake at North Randal, track today. He sold for $25 in pools totaling $445,000.
John D. Rockefeller told his friends yesterday, on his ninety-second birthday, that he hopes to pass one hundred.

NICE, France, July 8 (AP).--Andrew W.Mellon, United States Secretary of the Treasury, somewhat worn from his arduous negotiations at Paris and London, arrived here this afternoon for the vacation which he had put off until France and the United States could agree on the application of President Hoover's moratorium.

Representatives of shipping and towing companies operating about New York Harbor conferred in City Hall yesterday with Mayor Walker and Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, regarding possible solutions of the smoke nuisance caused by their vessels.

Max Schmeling will defend his world's heavyweight title against Primo Camera, Italian ring giant,in a fifteen-round bout to be held in September, probably in Jersey City. The definite announcement that a Schmeling-Carnera bout will be held

Sales of the General Motors Corporation to its dealers and those of dealers to consumers in June increased from the corresponding month of 1930, it was announced yesterday. It was the first month this year to show more sales to consumers than a year before.

Funeral services were held yesterday morning in the Riverside Memorial Chapel, at Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, for Charles Entratta, former henchman of Jack (Legs) Diamond, who was shot and killed on Monday in a bottle factory in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.

SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., July 8.Not every golfer can boast of a good start in tournament competition, but Chester T. Birch of Briar Hills, who took part in his first championship, came through in great style in the Westchester junior title play at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

Selling was resumed on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, with most of the leaders showing losses for the day, although some issues, including Electric Bond and Share, Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea, Woolworth of England and Duke Power were stronger.

CHICAGO, July 8.--Citizens, banks, investment houses, insurance companies and others who loaned cash to Chicago and its school system on which to operate in 1929, still have $38,662,000 owing to them.
Babe Ruth's twenty-first homer of the season was one of three roundtrip hits as the Yankees drubbed the Boston Red Sox, 13 to 3, in the first game of yesterday's double-header at the Yankee Stadium.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 8.-- The Seattle-to-Tokyo monoplane Fort Worth, piloted by Reg L. Robbins and H.S. Jones, was refueled successfully here late tonight by its trimotored mother ship and continued its journey toward the Bering Sea.

Harris M. Hanshue of Los Angeles, who was appointed president of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., last October, has resigned to devote all his time to the affairs of Western Air Express, of which he also is president. The announcement of Mr. Hanshue's resignation was made yesterday by C. M. Keys, chairman of the board of the air transport company.

WASHINGTON, July 8.-By approval of the Shipping Board, Albany became today a port of call for the American Hampton Roads Steamship Line, operating cargo steamer between the United States and British ports.

PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., July 9.Fire of undetermined origin, starting in the chemical manufacturing plant of the J. T. Baker Company here, just after 1:30 o'clock this morning, destroyed one large building, spread to three others,and at 4 A. M. was still burning and menacing a score of other structures on the Baker property.

The Board of Estimate will be asked to reconsider its plan to split bus franchises in Queens between the North Shore Bus Corporation and the Jamaica Central Railways, it was indicated yesterday. At its meeting tomorrow a demand will be made by a rival bus company, with the backing of a number of civic...
MONTREAL, July 8 (AP).--The Royals maintained their leading margin of three full games by splitting even with Newark today before a crowd of 5,200.

LATONIA, Ky., July 8 (AP).--Pittsburgher, Racing Commissioner Theodore Mueller's inconsistent 3-year-old son of In Memoriam and Wistaria, showed today that he is none the worse from wear and tear after his decisive defeat in the Latonia Derby when he romped home first in the Walnut Hills Handicap, feature today.

ROME, July 8.--Simultaneously with the arrival of Secretary of State Stimson in Rome today the Italian Government decided to propose a one-year arms truce if the Geneva arms parley is put off and revealed that France was about to submit new proposals for solution of the Italo-French naval controversy.
NEW YORK. Mrs. George Thompson has gone to Kindesrook, her place at the Onteora Club, Tannersville, N. Y., for the rest of the Summer.

GENEVA, July 8.--In the covenant of the League of Nations, conceived by Woodrow Wilson, there is nothing to indicate that it is concerned with poets, either famous or struggling.

While President Hoover's debt moratorium is a step in the right direction, more radical measures must be undertaken to save the world from a complete trade collapse a year from now, in the opinion of Sir Georga Paish, governor of the London School of Economics and former economic adviser to the British Government.

John Erskine, novelist and president of the Julliard School of Music, gave details yesterday afternoon concerning the story and music of "Jack and the Beanstalk," the American opera to be presented during the first or second week of next November by students of the schools in its new auditorium at Claremont Avenue and West 122d Street.

The first report from sea of one of the yachts in the transatlantic race that started from Newport last Saturday came to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday from the North German Lloyd liner Europa, which left here on Monday night for Cherbourg.

General Theatres Equipment, Inc., and its controlled company, the Fox Film Corporation, issued reports yesterday for the first three months of this year. The Fox Film Corporation showed net profit, before Federal income taxes, of $1,124,704, against $4,356,218 in the same period of 1930,...

WASHINGTON, July 8.--More than one-fourth of the internal revenue collections of $2,428,180,000 during the fiscal year ending June 30, or $671,616,166.47, came from the State of New York, according to Treasury figures issued today.

Four hundred college professors, teachers and students are to leave today for Italy on the motorship Saturnia of the Cosulich Line. The party will include a large delegation of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae under the leadership of Mrs. Philip A. Brennan, president, that is going to Rome to present a petition to Pope Plus XI for the canonization of Mother Seton.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP).--Philadelphia took a commanding lead in the American League race today by winning the fourth game of the series with Washington, 6 to 3, with a savage first-inning assault. The champions left Washington with a six and a half game hold on first place. Philadelphia won two, lost one and tied the other game of the fourgame series.

Master Sergeant Peter E. Boyle, World War veteran, who will retire at the close of thirty years of service next June and who is stationed on Governors Island with the Organized Reserve, will receive today a $6,000 bequest left to him by his old company commander, Colonel...

TOKYO, July 8.--The heavy rains of last night helped to quench race hatreds in Korea and no serious disturbances were reported today. Heijo was quiet, the Chinese returning home and reopening their shops. The bodies of eighty-eight dead have been recovered, including those of nine women.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--The discovery of identical defects in five of the eight new American 10,000-ton cruisers, the stern posts of which cracked while they were making full speed trials, was confirmed at the Navy Department this afternoon. The cruisers are the Chester, Chicago, Louisville, Augusta and Northampton.
TOKYO, July 8.--The large planet reported to have been found yesterday by Japanese astronomers has been found to be only a small asteroid.
TROY, N. Y.,July 8.-The State Boxing Commission suffered a triple setback today.

The stifling humidity continued yesterday through its third successive day, light winds affording only slight relief in the city. The temperature was not abnormally high for this time of year, although the thermometer remained above 71 throughout the day. It reached its maximum of 82 at 4 P.M. One prostration was reported.
ORADELL, N.J., July 8. -- Two cards under 80 mere posted at the Hackensack Golf Club today in the ninth annual father and son tournament of the New Jersey State Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--Demonstration flights of championship model airplanes were given before President Hoover and war and navy officials today by the four boys who won national honors in the recent elimination trials at Dayton.
While Germany was acting to straighten out her disordered finances yesterday, London sent out invitations for a Young Plan parley on July 17, to which the United States will send an observer.
Nine members of the United States track team which will participate in a series of meets in South Africa next month sailed aboard the Majestic yesterday.

BARCELONA, July 8.--High circles in the Macia party said tonight that the new Catalan constitutional project, which will be presented at a full assembly of the party Sunday, has been revised at secret meetings to give Catalonia complete regional independence and in several vital...

WASHINGTON, July 8.--The Hoover plan for a one-year moratorium on German reparations and intergovernmental debts "opened the gates to a return of prosperity," William R. Castle, Acting Secretary of State, said tonight in a radio speech over a nation-Wide hook-up.

The Union Oil Company of California for the six months ended June 30 reports a net profit of approximately $1,900,000 after depreciation, depletion, drilling and other expenses, equal to 43 cents a share on the 4,386,070 shares then outstanding. This compares with $5,150,000, or $1.20 a share, on the 4,304,453 shares outstanding in the first half of 1930.

Detectives from police headquarters and Newark, N.J., arrested Silas M. Newton, 43 years old, of 52 East Sixty-eighth Street, reputed to be a wealthy oil operator and amateur, golfer, yesterday on a charge of conspiring with two others to defraud a 74-year-old man of his life savings, amounting to $25,000.

The rapidity with which steel operations have recovered from the widespread July 4 holiday shutdowns is taken as an indication that present production is near the lowest point, according to the weekly reviews. It is stated that the opinion is general in the industry that the bottom will be reached this month and that August will show a slow but steady turn upward.

The "unpardonable sin" in presentday education is the refusal by educators to teach the child to face reality, Dr. William H. Kilpatrick, Professor of Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday in an address at the Horace Mann Auditorium. Children should be encouraged to ask questions and have the "why" of what they do explained, he told more than 200 teachers and school administrators.

The Second Bank and Trust Company of Hoboken will be absorbed this morning by the Trust Company of New Jersey of Jersey City, one of the three largest banks in Hudson County, it was announced last night by William C. Hawkes declared in a paper read last night in McMillin Academic Theatre as the first of series of addresses in which administrative officers will describe the college plans of Harvard, Swarthmore, Wabash...
NICE, France, July 9.--Charles Rancurel is going back to Devil's Island for a third time.

PARIS, July 9 (AP).--Rafael Martinez y Ortiz, Cuban Minister to France, died today after an illness of several days. Death was due to a liver disorder which his physicians thought they could not alleviate by an operation.

Vincent Richards, the defending champion in the United States professional championship now in progress at Forest Hills, cut loose in his match with Paul Heston yesterday and opened up his attacking style, coming in repeatedly and volleying brilliantly. Richards was not quite as impressive as against Behr on Wednesday but showed he is in great condition.

Urging lack of legal proof that John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, had any control over the Society of Tammany, an application was made to the Appellate Term yesterday in behalf of the society for a rehearing of the suit of John F. Lins, a sculptor, against the society ...

Seven men were injured, one seriously, when a stick of dynamite, which had failed to go off when it should have, exploded in the midst of twenty "sand-hogs" working sixty feet under the bed of the Harlem River yesterday morning.

BALTIMORE, July 9.--Mrs. Albert Forster's "Siamese twin" girl babies, bound together abdominally at birth and severed yesterday by surgeons in an operation almost unparalleled in surgery, were alive and "doing well," it was said at the hospital today.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., July 9.-- A long trail in quest of the Westchester junior title which he started five years ago came to a successful termination today when Elmer Wright of Leewood, pre-tournament favorite. conquered Chester T. Birch of Briar Hills, the medalist, 2 and 1, in the final at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

Yesterday at Forest Hills was the calm before the storm as the eight top seeded players in the national professional tennis championship moved into their allotted quarterfinal brackets with the loss of only a single set among them all.

ALBANY, July 9.--The appointment of three members of the commission to investigate and collect data relative to the present administration of justice was announced by Governor Roosevelt this afternoon. This completes the personnel of the commission.

NEWARK, N.J., July 9. -- Vice Chancellor Alonzo Church here today authorized Harry G. Hendricks and Oscar A. Klamer, receivers for the Earl Radio Corporation, to sue officers and directors of the corporation over acts in office for which they might be liable for damages to stockholders and creditors, and to sue the Radio Corporation of America under the Sherman anti-trust and the Clayton acts.

VIENNA, July 9.--Several thousand salary and pension contracts, valid in law, would be altered by an act of Parliament as a result of bills introduced in the Lower Chamber to effect a more economic administration of the State opera and State theatres and of the Creditanstalt, Austria's largest bank, which recently had to be taken over by the government.

ROME, July 9.--Premier Mussolini stressed to Secretary of State Stimson at a conference today that Italy favored vast cuts in armaments at the Geneva conference next year. They agreed that there must be no postponement of the arms parley, because its success would restore the confidence of the peoples of the world.

GARDONE RIVIERA, Italy, July 9.--Kaye Don, British sportsman, broke his own world's speedboat record today by piloting the motorboat Miss England II over a measured course at a rate of 110.223 miles an hour. He set the previous record of 103.49 miles an hour in Argentina earlier this year.

CENTRAL FALLS, R.I., July 9 (AP).--State police and firemen aided local police today in a fight with striking mill workers and sympathizers hurling stones. During the disturbance one policeman was beaten and six or seven persons arrested were taken away from police by the rioters.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 9. --Government ownership of public utilities and participation in industry and business, in competition with private enterprise and development were denounced alike by John Spargo, lecturer and writer, of Old Bennington, Vt., and by John B. Reynolds of Chicaco, vice president ...

MANILA, July 9.--Instructors in the National University and some other schools told their students today that they must march in a parade on Sunday, planned to convince Senator Harry B. Hawes of the desire of the Filipinos for independence, or lose 5 per cent of their grades in all subjects.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 8, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $971,000,000, an increase of $17,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $104,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1930.

Directors of Safeway Stores, Inc., and of MacMarr Stores, Inc., have approved a plan for the acquisition by Safeway of the assets and business of MacMarr. The details will be submitted soon to stockholders. Information has been received by Merrill, Lynch Co. that M.B. Skaggs, ...

Harry Conner, 41 years old, a private detective who was bodyguard to Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Bronx beer chief, during the General Sessions trial at which the racketeer was acquitted of threatening a detective with a pistol, was arrested on a warrant in the chambers of Chief City Magistrate McDonald late yesterday afternoon.

A decline of $24,000,000 in brokers' loans for the week ended on Wednesday was revealed in the report published yesterday by they Federal Rserve Bank of New York. The decline follows an advance of $73,000,000 a week ago, which interrupted a series of ten successive reductions. It brought the total of loans to $1,455,000,000, compared with the recent low record of $1,406,000,000 established two weeks ago.
CHICAGO, July 9.--Earl Howell Reed, etcher, writer and a leader among the Chicago artists, died here today. He was 68 years old and had been in ill health for two years.

SHANGHAI, July 9.--The third volume of Justice Richard Feetham's report dealing with the question of roads acquired by the Shanghai Settlement Council outside the settlement during the past year was issued today. These roads have been the subject of much controversy, the Chinese claiming they abrogate China's sovereign rights.

The incursion of the world's champion Philadelphia Athletics at Yankee Stadium yesterday failed to keep the Yankees from continuing on their winning way. Eighteen thousand fans saw Joe McCarthy's boys belt the champions with as much heartiness as they evinced against the lowly Red Sox the day before.
OTTAWA, July 9.--While the government crop reports have not so far made an estimate of this year's western wheat yield, yet they indicate it will be only slightly above 50 per cent of normal.

The move by President Hoover for a one-year suspension of payments on international governmental debts has had a profound effect in bettering sentiment in the business world, says The American Bankers Association Journal.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 9 (AP).-- Four of the fourteen planes participating in the national air tour failed to arrive here from Huntingdon, W. Va., today on account of a series of mishaps.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP).--The White House today was conducting an investigation into the sources of several published news stories which did not come through official channels.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., N.Y., July 9.--Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn gave a dinner last night at Little Cote for Mrs. Robert Franklin Adams, who is passing several weeks at the Meadow Club. Among her guests were Mrs. Eugene Gifford Grace, Mrs. Finley Peter Dunne, Mrs. Kirkwood Edmund Jewett, ...

MONTREAL. July 9.--Plans to oppose acceptance of the terms offered by the Securities Protective Committee for the reorganization of the Canada Power and Paper Corporation were formulated today by a committee representing the preferred shareholder's of the Belgo-Canadian Paper Company, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- There were 10,942 commercial failures in the country during the period Jan. 1 to April 30, with reported liabilities of $266,455,700 and estimated assets of $163,500,200, according to statistics furnished to the Department of Justice today by R.G. Dun Co., which is cooperating with the government in the general bankruptcy investigation conducted by the department.

LONDON, July 9.--Wedgwood Benn, Secretary of State for India, told the House of Commons today that Mahatma Gandhi was "a great force working for peace" and that he was rigorously observing the terms of his agreement with Lord Irwin.

HOUSTON Texas, July 9.--Worried over recent financial reverses and suffering from ill health, Robert Lee Henry, 67 years old, a member of Congress from Texas for twenty years, ended his life with a pistol shot at his residence here early this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--Opposition to summoning a national coal conference at this time was expressed by many of the bituminous coal operators who conferred with Secretaries Lamont and Doak today in regard to the troubled situation between the operators and the striking miners in the fields in Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Kentucky, Ohio and Virginia.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--The Mexican Government today transmitted to the State Department a strong protest over the arrest for contempt of court of Adolfo Dominguez, identified as a Mexican Consul at Chicago.

LONDON, July 9--The stock markets continued dull today, members being occupied with the account. Business was quiet, although a slightly better tendency developed toward the close as firmer Wall Street advices were received.

BOSTON, July 9.--William Watson Clark, who hasn't lost a game since May 5, still had that record unblemished when he completed today's labors against the Braves, who lost the opener to the Robins, 6 to 2. Clark now has recorded seven triumphs this season.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 29.-- Albert E. Sholes of this city, formerly editor, owner and publisher of The Flushing (L.I.) Daily Times, died today in a private hospital here. In a little more than a month he would have been 88 years old. Funeral services will be held Friday at 2 P.M.

Wolf Company sold the three-story frame flat with store at 539 Ocean Avenue, southwest corner of Bayview Avenue; the threestory six-family frame flat at 97 Old Bergen Road and the two-story brick taxpayer at 26 Siedler Street, near Clinton Avenue, Jersey City, to the Reml Corportaion.

PATERSON, N.J., July 29.-- Thirty-five men and women, picketers for the united front committee of the National Textile Workers, were arrested today as the police started to enforce their new rule against "unlawful" picketing.

LONDON, July 29.--David Lloyd George was resting quietly tonight after a severe abdominal operation this morning. The night bulletin of his physicians says: "Thus far Mr. Lloyd George's condition continues satisfactory."

The Quincy Mining Company will suspend the production of copper from Aug. 1 to Sept. 8, it was announced yesterday. Only construction and maintenance work will be done during the shut-down, which will affect mine, mill and smelter operations.

PARIS, July 30.--Paul Poiret backs up both modern and romantic movements with wool day frocks having straight pleated or wide unbrellagored skirts. Princess fitting or normal belting is favored. Decorative sleeves are varied by caps, and high or elbow cuffs are numerous.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--Manuel Quezon, president of the Philippine Senate and head of the Filipino independence mission to Washington, called on President Hoover today to say good-bye preparatory to his departure for Manila.

LONDON, July 30.--The stock markets were depressed today by a further rise in the bank rate to 4 per cent.
